newsitem.title: CANADA: Bulls seen returning to Canada stock markets.
newsitem.headline: Bulls seen returning to Canada stock markets.

text.p: Stock market bears have roamed through Canada's financial capital in the past few weeks, but the bulls may be rearing their heads again, some analysts said on Tuesday.

"I have a feeling the worst is over for the Canadian market. Particularly since I think the commodity sector is going to be doing considerably better," said Michael Metz, chief investment strategist at Oppenheimer & Co. Inc.
He said the U.S. market may remain pressured by interest rate concerns, but he forecast a divergence between markets in the United States and elsewhere.
Dunnery Best, director of private client investing at Canadian brokerage Midland Walwyn, said he believed the recent decline was a consolidation that was near its end.
"Has it run its course? I would say largely," Best said.

Despite rosy predictions by some strategists, technical analysts were pessimistic about longer-term prospects for the market and questioned the enthusiasm of market watchers who watch fundamental factors.

The Toronto Stock Exchange's key TSE 300 Composite Index, the bellwether for Canadian equities, has fallen about 10 percent from its all-time high of 6348.02 on March 11. As of Monday, the market was down 4.2 percent for the year.
Rising U.S. rates ignited a brushfire of market fears and prompted a raft of selling.

Concerns in Canada also were fanned by Bre-X Minerals Ltd., a Calgary, Alberta-based exploration firm whose shares plunged on March 26 when partner Freeport-McMoRan Copper & Gold Inc. said it found "insignificant" gold on its Indonesian gold property, touted as the largest gold find this century.
The Bre-X saga hit key Toronto gold issues hard.
Some analysts voiced hope that the 10 percent correction meant the market was poised to rebound.
"We are still bullish on the market," said Peter Dawkins, director of research at Midland.
"Our view is that this is a healthy correction," he added. Dawkins said the market should recover and break record levels later this year.
The TSE 300 was up 40.37 points at 5,719.70 on Tuesday, boosted by unexpectedly weak U.S. consumer price data, which offset a surprising climb in core producer prices last week.
But others observers maintained the recovery was temporary and that there was more blood-letting to come.
Katherine Beatty, a technical analyst with MMS International, called Tuesday's rally a "a knee-jerk reaction" and forecast at least another 5 percent pullback.
Technical analyst Joe Ismail at brokerage Maison Placements Canada said the market must rally by about 300 points in the next few days to prevent more losses.
"On the strength of that rally, we will be able to tell whether we are going to be able to make new highs or if we're going to backtrack," Ismail said.
He said the major Toronto sub-groups -- banks, base metals and precious metals, must participate to make a rebound last.
